trans-unit.source: [#$dp48]Copyright © 2008 [#$dp49]W3C® ([#$dp50]MIT, [#$dp51]ERCIM, [#$dp52]Keio), All Rights Reserved. W3C [#$dp53]liability, [#$dp54]trademark and [#$dp55]document use rules apply.

This specification defines the [#$dp60]ElementTraversal interface, which allows script navigation of the elements of a DOM tree, excluding all other nodes in the DOM, such as text nodes. It also provides an attribute to expose the number of child elements of an element. It is intended to provide a more convenient alternative to existing DOM navigation interfaces, with a low implementation footprint.

seg-source.mrk: This specification defines the [#$dp60]ElementTraversal interface, which allows script navigation of the elements of a DOM tree, excluding all other nodes in the DOM, such as text nodes.
It also provides an attribute to expose the number of child elements of an element.
It is intended to provide a more convenient alternative to existing DOM navigation interfaces, with a low implementation footprint.

target.mrk: This specification defines the [#$dp60]ElementTraversal interface, which allows script navigation of the elements of a DOM tree, excluding all other nodes in the DOM, such as text nodes.
It also provides an attribute to expose the number of child elements of an element.
It is intended to provide a more convenient alternative to existing DOM navigation interfaces, with a low implementation footprint.

trans-unit.source: This document has been reviewed by W3C Members, by software developers, and by other W3C groups and interested parties, and is endorsed by the Director as a W3C Recommendation. It is a stable document and may be used as reference material or cited from another document. W3C's role in making the Recommendation is to draw attention to the specification and to promote its widespread deployment. This enhances the functionality and interoperability of the Web.

trans-unit.source: The [#$dp87]ElementTraversal interface was originally published as part of the [#$dp88]SVG Tiny 1.2 specification in the SVG namespace. At the request of the SVG, CDF, JCP, and other groups, it was transferred to the WebAPI WG, and migrated to DOM and DOM namespace as a generic facility. It was transferred again when the WebApps WG took responsibility for the deliverables of the WebAPI WG.

seg-source.mrk: The [#$dp87]ElementTraversal interface was originally published as part of the [#$dp88]SVG Tiny 1.2 specification in the SVG namespace.
At the request of the SVG, CDF, JCP, and other groups, it was transferred to the WebAPI WG, and migrated to DOM and DOM namespace as a generic facility.
It was transferred again when the WebApps WG took responsibility for the deliverables of the WebAPI WG.

target.mrk: The [#$dp87]ElementTraversal interface was originally published as part of the [#$dp88]SVG Tiny 1.2 specification in the SVG namespace.
At the request of the SVG, CDF, JCP, and other groups, it was transferred to the WebAPI WG, and migrated to DOM and DOM namespace as a generic facility.
It was transferred again when the WebApps WG took responsibility for the deliverables of the WebAPI WG.

trans-unit.source: The DOM Level 1 [#$dp185]Node interface defines 11 node types, but most commonly authors wish to operate solely on [#$dp186]nodeType 1, the [#$dp187]Element node. Other node types include the [#$dp188]Document element and [#$dp189]Text nodes, which include whitespace and line breaks. DOM 1 node traversal includes all of these node types, which is often a source of confusion for authors and which requires an extra step for authors to confirm that the expected [#$dp190]Element node interfaces are available. This introduces an additional performance constraint.

seg-source.mrk: The DOM Level 1 [#$dp185]Node interface defines 11 node types, but most commonly authors wish to operate solely on [#$dp186]nodeType 1, the [#$dp187]Element node.
Other node types include the [#$dp188]Document element and [#$dp189]Text nodes, which include whitespace and line breaks.

DOM 1 node traversal includes all of these node types, which is often a source of confusion for authors and which requires an extra step for authors to confirm that the expected [#$dp190]Element node interfaces are available.
This introduces an additional performance constraint.

target.mrk: The DOM Level 1 [#$dp185]Node interface defines 11 node types, but most commonly authors wish to operate solely on [#$dp186]nodeType 1, the [#$dp187]Element node.
Other node types include the [#$dp188]Document element and [#$dp189]Text nodes, which include whitespace and line breaks.

DOM 1 node traversal includes all of these node types, which is often a source of confusion for authors and which requires an extra step for authors to confirm that the expected [#$dp190]Element node interfaces are available.
This introduces an additional performance constraint.

trans-unit.source: [#$dp193]ElementTraversal is an interface which allows the author to restrict navigation to [#$dp194]Element nodes. It permits navigation from an element to its first element child, its last element child, and to its next or previous element siblings. Because the implementation exposes only the element nodes, the memory and computational footprint of the DOM representation can be optimized for constrained devices.

seg-source.mrk: [#$dp193]ElementTraversal is an interface which allows the author to restrict navigation to [#$dp194]Element nodes.
It permits navigation from an element to its first element child, its last element child, and to its next or previous element siblings.
Because the implementation exposes only the element nodes, the memory and computational footprint of the DOM representation can be optimized for constrained devices.

target.mrk: [#$dp193]ElementTraversal is an interface which allows the author to restrict navigation to [#$dp194]Element nodes.
It permits navigation from an element to its first element child, its last element child, and to its next or previous element siblings.
Because the implementation exposes only the element nodes, the memory and computational footprint of the DOM representation can be optimized for constrained devices.

trans-unit.source: The DOM Level 1 [#$dp197]Node interface also defines the [#$dp198]childNodes attribute, which is a live list of all child nodes of the node; the [#$dp199]childNodes list has a [#$dp200]length attribute to expose the total number of child nodes of all [#$dp201]nodeTypes, useful for preprocessing operations and calculations before, or instead of, looping through the child nodes. The [#$dp202]ElementTraversal interface has a similar attribute, [#$dp203]childElementCount, that reports only the number of [#$dp204]Element nodes, which is often what is desired for such operations.

seg-source.mrk: The DOM Level 1 [#$dp197]Node interface also defines the [#$dp198]childNodes attribute, which is a live list of all child nodes of the node; the [#$dp199]childNodes list has a [#$dp200]length attribute to expose the total number of child nodes of all [#$dp201]nodeTypes, useful for preprocessing operations and calculations before, or instead of, looping through the child nodes.

The [#$dp202]ElementTraversal interface has a similar attribute, [#$dp203]childElementCount, that reports only the number of [#$dp204]Element nodes, which is often what is desired for such operations.

target.mrk: The DOM Level 1 [#$dp197]Node interface also defines the [#$dp198]childNodes attribute, which is a live list of all child nodes of the node; the [#$dp199]childNodes list has a [#$dp200]length attribute to expose the total number of child nodes of all [#$dp201]nodeTypes, useful for preprocessing operations and calculations before, or instead of, looping through the child nodes.

The [#$dp202]ElementTraversal interface has a similar attribute, [#$dp203]childElementCount, that reports only the number of [#$dp204]Element nodes, which is often what is desired for such operations.

trans-unit.source: This specification does not include the complete list of attributes, methods, and other interfaces available on the [#$dp209]Element object. Additional interfaces are found in other specifications, notably the DOM Core specifications.

trans-unit.source: Sometimes, for readability, conformance requirements are phrased as requirements on elements, attributes, methods, interfaces, properties or functions. In all cases these are conformance requirements on implementations. A conforming implementation of this specification meets all requirements identified by the use of these terms, within the scope of its language bindings.

seg-source.mrk: Sometimes, for readability, conformance requirements are phrased as requirements on elements, attributes, methods, interfaces, properties or functions.
In all cases these are conformance requirements on implementations.
A conforming implementation of this specification meets all requirements identified by the use of these terms, within the scope of its language bindings.

target.mrk: Sometimes, for readability, conformance requirements are phrased as requirements on elements, attributes, methods, interfaces, properties or functions.
In all cases these are conformance requirements on implementations.
A conforming implementation of this specification meets all requirements identified by the use of these terms, within the scope of its language bindings.

trans-unit.source: The [#$dp225]ElementTraversal interface is a set of read-only attributes which allow an author to easily navigate between elements in a document. In conforming implementations of Element Traversal, all objects that implement [#$dp226]Element must also implement the [#$dp227]ElementTraversal interface. Four of the attributes, [#$dp228]firstElementChild, [#$dp229]lastElementChild, [#$dp230]previousElementSibling, and [#$dp231]nextElementSibling, each provide a live reference to another element with the defined relationship to the current element, if the related element exists. The fifth attribute, [#$dp232]childElementCount, exposes the number of child elements of an element, for preprocessing before navigation. A conforming User Agent must implement all five attributes. A User Agent may implement similar interfaces in other specifications, but such implementation is not required for conformance to this specification, if the User Agent is designed for a minimal code footprint.

seg-source.mrk: The [#$dp225]ElementTraversal interface is a set of read-only attributes which allow an author to easily navigate between elements in a document.
In conforming implementations of Element Traversal, all objects that implement [#$dp226]Element must also implement the [#$dp227]ElementTraversal interface.

Four of the attributes, [#$dp228]firstElementChild, [#$dp229]lastElementChild, [#$dp230]previousElementSibling, and [#$dp231]nextElementSibling, each provide a live reference to another element with the defined relationship to the current element, if the related element exists.
The fifth attribute, [#$dp232]childElementCount, exposes the number of child elements of an element, for preprocessing before navigation.
A conforming User Agent must implement all five attributes.

A User Agent may implement similar interfaces in other specifications, but such implementation is not required for conformance to this specification, if the User Agent is designed for a minimal code footprint.

target.mrk: The [#$dp225]ElementTraversal interface is a set of read-only attributes which allow an author to easily navigate between elements in a document.
In conforming implementations of Element Traversal, all objects that implement [#$dp226]Element must also implement the [#$dp227]ElementTraversal interface.

Four of the attributes, [#$dp228]firstElementChild, [#$dp229]lastElementChild, [#$dp230]previousElementSibling, and [#$dp231]nextElementSibling, each provide a live reference to another element with the defined relationship to the current element, if the related element exists.
The fifth attribute, [#$dp232]childElementCount, exposes the number of child elements of an element, for preprocessing before navigation.
A conforming User Agent must implement all five attributes.

A User Agent may implement similar interfaces in other specifications, but such implementation is not required for conformance to this specification, if the User Agent is designed for a minimal code footprint.

trans-unit.source: This interface must be implemented on all [#$dp235]Elements, regardless of their namespace. EntityReference nodes are not visible to the Element Traversal mechanism; if the tree-walker encounters an EntityReference node, it descends into it without informing the caller, and processes any children as if they had been present at the place where the entity node was found. Navigation must be irrespective of namespace, e.g. if an element in the HTML namespace is followed by element in the SVG namespace, the [#$dp236]nextElementSibling attribute on the HTML element will return the SVG element.

seg-source.mrk: This interface must be implemented on all [#$dp235]Elements, regardless of their namespace.

EntityReference nodes are not visible to the Element Traversal mechanism; if the tree-walker encounters an EntityReference node, it descends into it without informing the caller, and processes any children as if they had been present at the place where the entity node was found.

Navigation must be irrespective of namespace, e.g. if an element in the HTML namespace is followed by element in the SVG namespace, the [#$dp236]nextElementSibling attribute on the HTML element will return the SVG element.

target.mrk: This interface must be implemented on all [#$dp235]Elements, regardless of their namespace.

EntityReference nodes are not visible to the Element Traversal mechanism; if the tree-walker encounters an EntityReference node, it descends into it without informing the caller, and processes any children as if they had been present at the place where the entity node was found.

Navigation must be irrespective of namespace, e.g. if an element in the HTML namespace is followed by element in the SVG namespace, the [#$dp236]nextElementSibling attribute on the HTML element will return the SVG element.

trans-unit.source: Accessing this attribute of an element must return a reference to the first child node of that element which is of [#$dp241]nodeType 1, as an [#$dp242]Element object. If the element on which this attribute is accessed does not have any child nodes, or if none of those child nodes are element nodes, then this attribute must return null.

If the element on which this attribute is accessed does not have any child nodes, or if none of those child nodes are element nodes, then this attribute must return null.

trans-unit.source: Accessing this attribute of an element must return a reference to the last child node of that element which is of [#$dp247]nodeType 1, as an [#$dp248]Element object. If the element on which this attribute is accessed does not have any child nodes, or if none of those child nodes are element nodes, then this attribute must return null.

seg-source.mrk: Accessing this attribute of an element must return a reference to the last child node of that element which is of [#$dp247]nodeType 1, as an [#$dp248]Element object.
If the element on which this attribute is accessed does not have any child nodes, or if none of those child nodes are element nodes, then this attribute must return null.

target.mrk: Accessing this attribute of an element must return a reference to the last child node of that element which is of [#$dp247]nodeType 1, as an [#$dp248]Element object.
If the element on which this attribute is accessed does not have any child nodes, or if none of those child nodes are element nodes, then this attribute must return null.

trans-unit.source: Accessing this attribute of an element must return a reference to the sibling node of that element which most immediately precedes that element in document order, and which is of [#$dp253]nodeType 1, as an [#$dp254]Element object. If the element on which this attribute is accessed does not have any preceding sibling nodes, or if none of those preceding sibling nodes are element nodes, then this attribute must return null.

seg-source.mrk: Accessing this attribute of an element must return a reference to the sibling node of that element which most immediately precedes that element in document order, and which is of [#$dp253]nodeType 1, as an [#$dp254]Element object.
If the element on which this attribute is accessed does not have any preceding sibling nodes, or if none of those preceding sibling nodes are element nodes, then this attribute must return null.

target.mrk: Accessing this attribute of an element must return a reference to the sibling node of that element which most immediately precedes that element in document order, and which is of [#$dp253]nodeType 1, as an [#$dp254]Element object.
If the element on which this attribute is accessed does not have any preceding sibling nodes, or if none of those preceding sibling nodes are element nodes, then this attribute must return null.

trans-unit.source: Accessing this attribute of an element must return a reference to the sibling node of that element which most immediately follows that element in document order, and which is of [#$dp259]nodeType 1, as an [#$dp260]Element object. If the element on which this attribute is accessed does not have any following sibling nodes, or if none of those following sibling nodes are element nodes, then this attribute must return null.

seg-source.mrk: Accessing this attribute of an element must return a reference to the sibling node of that element which most immediately follows that element in document order, and which is of [#$dp259]nodeType 1, as an [#$dp260]Element object.
If the element on which this attribute is accessed does not have any following sibling nodes, or if none of those following sibling nodes are element nodes, then this attribute must return null.

target.mrk: Accessing this attribute of an element must return a reference to the sibling node of that element which most immediately follows that element in document order, and which is of [#$dp259]nodeType 1, as an [#$dp260]Element object.
If the element on which this attribute is accessed does not have any following sibling nodes, or if none of those following sibling nodes are element nodes, then this attribute must return null.

trans-unit.source: Accessing this attribute of an element must return the current number of child nodes of that element which are of [#$dp265]nodeType 1. An implementation may store this number, or it may calculate it upon accessing this attribute, but the number must always represent the number of child element nodes at the time the attribute is accessed. Only immediate child nodes must be counted, e.g. elements which are child nodes of one of the child nodes of the element on which the attribute is accessed are not included in this count. If the element on which this attribute is accessed does not have any child nodes, or if none of those child nodes are element nodes, then this attribute must return 0.

seg-source.mrk: Accessing this attribute of an element must return the current number of child nodes of that element which are of [#$dp265]nodeType 1.

An implementation may store this number, or it may calculate it upon accessing this attribute, but the number must always represent the number of child element nodes at the time the attribute is accessed.
Only immediate child nodes must be counted, e.g. elements which are child nodes of one of the child nodes of the element on which the attribute is accessed are not included in this count.
If the element on which this attribute is accessed does not have any child nodes, or if none of those child nodes are element nodes, then this attribute must return 0.

target.mrk: Accessing this attribute of an element must return the current number of child nodes of that element which are of [#$dp265]nodeType 1.

An implementation may store this number, or it may calculate it upon accessing this attribute, but the number must always represent the number of child element nodes at the time the attribute is accessed.
Only immediate child nodes must be counted, e.g. elements which are child nodes of one of the child nodes of the element on which the attribute is accessed are not included in this count.
If the element on which this attribute is accessed does not have any child nodes, or if none of those child nodes are element nodes, then this attribute must return 0.

<g id='shapeGroup'>
<rect id='rect1' x='5' y='5' width='310' height='220' rx='15' ry='15' fill='skyblue'/> <rect id='rect2' x='15' y='15' width='210' height='180' rx='15' ry='15' fill='cornflowerblue'/>
<ellipse id='ellipse1' cx='90' cy='70' rx='50' ry='30' fill='yellow' stroke='orange'/>
<path id='path1' stroke-width='15' stroke='orange' fill='none' stroke-linecap='round' d='M25,150 C180,180 290,0 400,140 S420,100 460,90'/> <text id='text1' x='0' y='0' font-size='35' fill='yellow' stroke='orange' stroke-width='2' stroke-linejoin='round' font-weight='bold'> <textPath id='textPath1' xlink:href="#path1">when life gives you lemons...</textPath></text>
</g>

seg-source.mrk: // step through child elements one by one
// then navigate to next child element

target.mrk: // step through child elements one by one
// then navigate to next child element

trans-unit.source: Where el is the 'g' element with the 'id' "shapeGroup", nodeCount will have the value 11. firstNode will be a [#$dp299]Text node ([#$dp300]nodeType of 3), and is not equivalent to the first assigned value of childEl, which is an [#$dp301]Element node ([#$dp302]nodeType of 1) with the 'id' "rect1". The while loop will cycle 4 more times, iterating through the sibling [#$dp303]Element nodes, respectively "rect2", "ellipse1", "path1", and "text1". The last value of childEl will be null, as "text1" does not have a next element sibling, though it does have a next node sibling.

seg-source.mrk: Where el is the 'g' element with the 'id' "shapeGroup", nodeCount will have the value 11.

firstNode will be a [#$dp299]Text node ([#$dp300]nodeType of 3), and is not equivalent to the first assigned value of childEl, which is an [#$dp301]Element node ([#$dp302]nodeType of 1) with the 'id' "rect1".
The while loop will cycle 4 more times, iterating through the sibling [#$dp303]Element nodes, respectively "rect2", "ellipse1", "path1", and "text1".
The last value of childEl will be null, as "text1" does not have a next element sibling, though it does have a next node sibling.

target.mrk: Where el is the 'g' element with the 'id' "shapeGroup", nodeCount will have the value 11.

firstNode will be a [#$dp299]Text node ([#$dp300]nodeType of 3), and is not equivalent to the first assigned value of childEl, which is an [#$dp301]Element node ([#$dp302]nodeType of 1) with the 'id' "rect1".
The while loop will cycle 4 more times, iterating through the sibling [#$dp303]Element nodes, respectively "rect2", "ellipse1", "path1", and "text1".
The last value of childEl will be null, as "text1" does not have a next element sibling, though it does have a next node sibling.

trans-unit.source: Note that an SVG [#$dp306]'text' element is not the same as a [#$dp307]Text node. Note also that the SVG [#$dp308]'textPath' child element of the [#$dp309]'text' element is not included in the iteration, as it is not a sibling of childEl.

seg-source.mrk: Note that an SVG [#$dp306]'text' element is not the same as a [#$dp307]Text node.
Note also that the SVG [#$dp308]'textPath' child element of the [#$dp309]'text' element is not included in the iteration, as it is not a sibling of childEl.

target.mrk: Note that an SVG [#$dp306]'text' element is not the same as a [#$dp307]Text node.
Note also that the SVG [#$dp308]'textPath' child element of the [#$dp309]'text' element is not included in the iteration, as it is not a sibling of childEl.

trans-unit.source: This specification provides an interface that has functional similarity to the DOM navigation attributes of DOM 1 Core, but operates only on element nodes, not other node types. The most comparable DOM 1 Core attributes are [#$dp318]firstChild, [#$dp319]lastChild, [#$dp320]previousSibling, [#$dp321]nextSibling, and [#$dp322]nodeList.length.

seg-source.mrk: This specification provides an interface that has functional similarity to the DOM navigation attributes of DOM 1 Core, but operates only on element nodes, not other node types.
The most comparable DOM 1 Core attributes are [#$dp318]firstChild, [#$dp319]lastChild, [#$dp320]previousSibling, [#$dp321]nextSibling, and [#$dp322]nodeList.length.

target.mrk: This specification provides an interface that has functional similarity to the DOM navigation attributes of DOM 1 Core, but operates only on element nodes, not other node types.
The most comparable DOM 1 Core attributes are [#$dp318]firstChild, [#$dp319]lastChild, [#$dp320]previousSibling, [#$dp321]nextSibling, and [#$dp322]nodeList.length.

trans-unit.source: Document Object Model Level 2 [#$dp327]Traversal & Range is a comprehensive document navigation specification, but may require more device and implementor resources than Element Traversal. As Element Traversal consists of an optimized subset of the functionality of DOM 2 [#$dp328]Traversal, a user agent that implements both may do so in a way that leverages the functionality of Traversal.

seg-source.mrk: Document Object Model Level 2 [#$dp327]Traversal & Range is a comprehensive document navigation specification, but may require more device and implementor resources than Element Traversal.

As Element Traversal consists of an optimized subset of the functionality of DOM 2 [#$dp328]Traversal, a user agent that implements both may do so in a way that leverages the functionality of Traversal.

target.mrk: Document Object Model Level 2 [#$dp327]Traversal & Range is a comprehensive document navigation specification, but may require more device and implementor resources than Element Traversal.

As Element Traversal consists of an optimized subset of the functionality of DOM 2 [#$dp328]Traversal, a user agent that implements both may do so in a way that leverages the functionality of Traversal.

trans-unit.source: This is a supplementary specification to [#$dp333]DOM 3 Core.

trans-unit.source: There are no known security considerations involved in the implementation or use of the [#$dp340]ElementTraversal interface. This section shall be revised if future security considerations are discovered.

trans-unit.source: Returns the previous sibling element node of this element. null if this element has no element sibling nodes that come before this one in the document tree.

trans-unit.source: [#$dp459]Document Object Model - Level 1 Core, V. Apparao, S. Byrne, M. Champion, S. Isaacs, I. Jacobs, A. Le Hors, G. Nicol, J. Robie, R. Sutor, C. Wilson, L. Wood, Editors. World Wide Web Consortium, 1 October 1998. A standard set of objects for representing HTML and XML documents, a standard model of how these objects can be combined, and a standard interface for accessing and manipulating them.

seg-source.mrk: [#$dp459]Document Object Model - Level 1 Core, V. Apparao, S. Byrne, M. Champion, S. Isaacs, I. Jacobs, A. Le Hors, G. Nicol, J. Robie, R. Sutor, C. Wilson, L. Wood, Editors.
A standard set of objects for representing HTML and XML documents, a standard model of how these objects can be combined, and a standard interface for accessing and manipulating them.

A standard set of objects for representing HTML and XML documents, a standard model of how these objects can be combined, and a standard interface for accessing and manipulating them.

trans-unit.source: [#$dp471]The SVG Micro DOM (uDOM), O. Andersson, R. Berjon, E. Dahlström, A. Emmons, J. Ferraiolo, V. Hardy, S. Hayman, D. Jackson, C. Lilley, A. Neumann, C. Northway, A. Quint, N. Ramani, D. Schepers, A. Shellshear, Editors. World Wide Web Consortium, 10 August 2006. The proposed ElementTraversal interface in SVG.

trans-unit.source: [#$dp476]Document Object Model (DOM) Level 2 Traversal and Range Specification, J. Kesselman, J. Robie, M. Champion, P. Sharpe, V. Apparao, L. Wood, Editors. World Wide Web Consortium, 13 November 2000. A set of platform- and language-neutral interfaces that allow programs and scripts to dynamically traverse and identify a range of content in a document.

seg-source.mrk: [#$dp476]Document Object Model (DOM) Level 2 Traversal and Range Specification, J. Kesselman, J. Robie, M. Champion, P. Sharpe, V. Apparao, L. Wood, Editors.
A set of platform- and language-neutral interfaces that allow programs and scripts to dynamically traverse and identify a range of content in a document.

target.mrk: [#$dp476]Document Object Model (DOM) Level 2 Traversal and Range Specification, J. Kesselman, J. Robie, M. Champion, P. Sharpe, V. Apparao, L. Wood, Editors.
A set of platform- and language-neutral interfaces that allow programs and scripts to dynamically traverse and identify a range of content in a document.

trans-unit.source: [#$dp481]Document Object Model (DOM) Level 3 Core Specification, A. Le Hors, P. Le Hégaret, L. Wood, G. Nicol, J. Robie, M. Champion, S. Byrne, Editors. World Wide Web Consortium, 07 April 2004. A platform- and language-neutral interface that allows programs and scripts to dynamically access and update the content, structure and style of documents.

seg-source.mrk: [#$dp481]Document Object Model (DOM) Level 3 Core Specification, A. Le Hors, P. Le Hégaret, L. Wood, G. Nicol, J. Robie, M. Champion, S. Byrne, Editors.

A platform- and language-neutral interface that allows programs and scripts to dynamically access and update the content, structure and style of documents.

trans-unit.source: The editor would like to thank the following people for contributing to this specification: David Andersson, Robin Berjon, Jean-Yves Bitterlich, Sergiu Dumitriu, Daniel Glazman, Bjoern Hoehrmann, Kurosawa Takeshi, Chris Lilley, Charles McCathieNevile, Cameron McCormack, Simon Pieters, Nandini Ramani, Jonas Sicking, Andrew Sledd, Josh Soref, Anne van Kesteren, Boris Zbarsky, and Mohamed Zergaoui. The editor would additionally like to thank the SVG WG for producing the draft [[#$dp486]SVGD] on which this was initially based.
